   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS:72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG (6), systolic
   CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus admitted,
   sleep apnea on BIPAP to SICU from OSH([**Location (un) 2408**]) with confusion s/p fall
   found on Head CT to have subdural hematoma s/p evacuation/burr hole. On
   arrival was in afib managed with IV metoprolol given NPO and on BIPAP
   s/p extubation post burrhole/evacuation. Cards consult for assitance
   with cardiac management given hx, with assessment that there was no
   evidence CHF/active ischemia and to continue cards meds (plavix/asa
   were being held given head bleed. Had been holding his lasix and
   antihtn's (lisinopril 10, carvedilol 12.5) and pt received 3L IV fluids
   in OR. Overnight became more tachypneic with poor UOP received 10mg IV
   lasix an [**9-5**] 9am then another 20mg IV with only small increase in UOP
   but hypotensive to mid 80s with boluses. Noted by cards on f/u to be
   clinically volume overload consistent with CVP of 24 with Bedside Echo
   poor quality but showed Afib, stable severe LV dilation with EF 15%,
   elevated LA pressure, 1 + MR with no priors for comparison. Initial CXR
   on admission showed pulmonary congestion, repeat CXR at this point did
   not show any change. Also noted to have worsening Cr from 1.3 on
   admission to 1.9 currently. He was at this point admitted to CCU
   service for management heart failure.
   .
   On transfer to cards he was +ve 1500cc for the day with CVP 24.
   Switched to lasix gtt, with goal UOP 100-150cc/hr. He restarted his
   carvedilol although lisinopril was held given his renal failure.
   .
   On review of systems,per daughter pt had "platelet allergy in
   ambulance, hx unclear. he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep
   venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery,
   myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools.he
   denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock
   or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.
   .
   Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea
   on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema,
   palpitations, syncope or presyncope.
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: DM, CAD s/p MI, CABG, Afib, CHF w/ EF 15% s/p
   ICD, sleep apnea on BIPAP
   Cardiac Risk Factors include diabetes, CAD.
   .
   HOME MEDICATIONS: ASA 81 mg, Carvedilol 12.5 mg [**Hospital1 **], Lisinopril 10 mg
   daily, Plavix 75 mg daily, Lasix 40 mg [**Hospital1 **], Zocor 40 mg q day, KCl 20

   . .
   LABS/STUDIEs:
   TELEMETRY: AF intermittenly paced
   ECG [**2109-2-2**]: AF with intermitted ventricular pacing. LBBB in native
   beats.
   Head CT:
   1. Large lentiform predominantly hypodense extra-axial collection along
   the left cerebral hemisphere, with hyperdense rim and internal
   septations, compatible with chronic subdural hematoma. This collection
   causes substantial mass effect, including rightward subfalcine
   herniation and early left uncal herniation. Findings not changed from
   one day prior.
   2. Hypodense evolving subacute posterior right temporal lobe infarct,
   in the territory of the right MCA, unchanged.
   .
   CXR: A dual-lead pacemaker generator overlies the left upper
   hemithorax, with leads terminating in the right atrium and right
   ventricle. Median sternotomy wires are in place. Lung volumes are low.
   Bilaterally, there is perihilar vascular congestion. The heart is
   enlarged. There may be a trace right effusion, but there is no left
   pleural effusion or consolidation. There is no pneumothorax.
   IMPRESSION: Cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion.
   .
   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM:  [**2109-2-3**]
   The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is moderately dilated.
   Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular
   cavity is severely dilated. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a
   focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 15 %). The
   right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with mild global free
   wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic
   valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. No aortic regurgitation is
   seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened. Mild (1+)
   mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity
   of mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] The left
   ventricular inflow pattern suggests a restrictive filling abnormality,
   with elevated left atrial pressure. There is a very small pericardial
   effusion.
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-myocardial infarction (MI) and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 15%, atrial fibrillation (AFib), and diabetes mellitus. The patient was admitted to the surgical intensive care unit (SICU) from the operating room (OSH) after a fall and subsequent burr hole/evacuation for a subdural hematoma. The patient was found to be in AFib upon arrival and managed with intravenous metoprolol. The patient is currently on bipap and extubated post-burrhole/evacuation.

The patient's medical history is significant for CAD, MI, CABG, AFib, CHF with EF 15% post-implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), and sleep apnea on bipap. The patient's cardiac risk factors include diabetes and CAD.

The patient's current medications include aspirin (ASA) 81 mg, carvedilol 12.5 mg, lisinopril 10 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, furosemide (Lasix) 1-5 mg/hr IV drip infusion, titrated to negative 50-100cc/hr, heparin 5000 units subcutaneously every third day, phenytoin sodium extended-release 100 mg orally every third day, ondansetron 4 mg IV every eight hours as needed for nausea, and hydralazine 10 mg IV every six hours if systolic blood pressure (SBP) >160 mmHg.

The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies. The patient's social history includes being retired, living with his wife, and being independent in activities of daily living (ADLs). The patient has a history of smoking in the past. The patient's family history is noncontributory for CAD.

Laboratory data shows an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 19.8 thousand/mm^3, hematocrit (Hct) levels ranging from 43-48.3%, platelet count of 289-293 thousand/mm^3, creatinine (Cr) levels of 1.8-2.1 mg/dL, blood glucose levels ranging from 87-200 mg/dL, and electrolyte imbalances including potassium (K+) levels of 3.5-4.8 mEq/L, sodium (Na+) levels of 138-142 mEq/L, and chloride (Cl-) levels of 98-100 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination findings include a temperature of 36.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate (HR) of 114 beats per minute, blood pressure (BP) ranging from 131/86 mmHg to 97/78 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) of 28 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 99% on bipap, and central venous pressure (CVP) of 17 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented to person but disoriented to place and time. The patient has irregularly irregular heart rhythm, full neck veins, and mild crackles in the bases of the lungs bilaterally. The patient also has staples in

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG). He presents with symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF) and atrial fibrillation. The patient also has a subdural hematoma, which has been evacuated. He is experiencing volume overload, likely due to his atrial fibrillation and poor forward flow. The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is on diuretics to manage this condition. Additionally, the patient has a history of sleep apnea and is being treated with CPAP.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiac Complications:
   - CHF exacerbation: The patient's symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and fluid overload suggest worsening heart failure.
   - Arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation increases the risk of future arrhythmias, which can lead to hemodynamic instability.
   - Coronary artery disease progression: Given the patient's history of CAD and CABG, there is a risk of further blockages or ischemic events.

2. Neurological Complications:
   - Recurrence of subdural hematoma: Although the patient had a subdural hematoma that was evacuated, there is still a risk of recurrence due to his anticoagulation therapy and potential bleeding risk.
   - Cognitive decline: The patient may be at risk of cognitive decline due to

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure secondary to exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and subsequent hypoxic brain injury.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.2°C (97.1°F), heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure of 114/88 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96% on bipap mask. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals a paced rhythm with frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), right pupil larger than the left and asymmetrically positioned downwards and to the right, full distal pulses bilaterally, and use of accessory muscles for breathing. The patient's neurological examination shows orientation to person, place, and month, but not date. Extremities are cool with dopplerable pulses, and no edema is present.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 19.8 K/uL, elevated hemoglobin of 13.9 g/dL, slightly low sodium level of 134 mg/dL, normal potassium level of 4.3 mEq/L, slightly elevated chloride level of 103 mEq/L, normal bicarbonate level of 26 mEq/L, and elevated BUN and creatinine levels indicating possible kidney dysfunction.

Radiology images and cardiac enzyme levels are also provided, but they are not mentioned in the given prompt.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been intubated for an extended period, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory symptoms and cultures will be necessary.

2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)/Pulmonary embolism (PE): Immobility, trauma, and underlying hypercoagulability state increase the risk of DVT and subsequent PE. Surveillance for signs of DVT/PE and consideration of prophylactic anticoagulation are recommended.

3. Central nervous system (CNS) complications: The patient's subdural hematoma may lead to further neurological deterioration. Monitoring for changes in mental status, motor function, and pupillary response is crucial.

4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and presence of PVCs indicate an increased risk for additional cardiac arrhythmias. Continuous cardiac monitoring and antiarrhythmic therapy may be required.

5. Infection: Prolonged ICU stay increases the risk of hospital-acquired infections. Regular assessment

6. Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism recurrence.

8. Gastrointestinal bleeding or stress ulcer complications.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He also has a history of systolic congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15% and atrial fibrillation. The patient underwent burr hole evacuation for a subdural hematoma and is currently experiencing volume overload clinically, despite no change on chest X-ray. 

The patient's overnight events include becoming more dyspneic and agitated, with an attempt to restart lasix. The ABG values were skewed due to low oxygen levels. The patient's condition did not improve, so a lasix bolus was given. The patient continued to experience symptoms, including tachycardia and increased central venous pressure (CVP). An EKG showed no significant changes, suggesting possible atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing. The night nurse increased the lasix bolus and administered 500 mg of IV diuril, which worked overnight. An electrophysiologist was scheduled to interrogate the pacemaker, but the patient was too short of breath to proceed. Neurosurgery placed orders to start Plavix three days post-procedure and switch from dilantin to keppra.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 89/67 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's heart rhythm is ventricular paced, and the CVP is elevated at 16-18 mmHg. The patient's fluid balance shows a negative balance of 2283 mL since 10 AM, with total inputs of 1023 mL and total outputs of 3306 mL. The patient is receiving respiratory support with a bipap mask and is on IV fluids.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral crackles in the lungs, no significant leg edema, and staples in place on the left scalp. Neurological examination shows orientation to person and month but not year, with ability to move all four extremities spontaneously. The patient's labs indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient's symptoms of dyspnea, agitation, tachycardia, and elevated CVP suggest fluid overload. The patient responded to lasix and diuril, indicating a positive response to diuresis. Continuing lasix gtt and monitoring CVP are important to prevent fluid overload.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia and EKG findings suggest atrial fibrillation. Increasing carvedilol and discussing with an outpatient cardiologist about anticoagulation therapy (Coumadin) are necessary to manage this condition.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of cardiac disease.
- He was admitted to the ICU after undergoing neurosurgical intervention.
- The patient's chief complaint is dyspnea and agitation.
- Overnight events include an increase in dyspnea, agitation, and tachycardia, with a CVP of 16-18.
- An EKG showed no significant changes, but there was a suspicion of atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing.
- The patient received a lasix bolus and IV diuretic, which seemed to improve his symptoms.
- Neurosurgery placed orders for starting Plavix three days post-procedure and switching from dilantin to keppra.
- Allergies: No known drug allergies.
- Medications: Omeprazole, furosemide, heparin sodium, and dextrose.
- Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for dyspnea and agitation.
- Vital signs: Tcurrent 36.1°C, HR 98 bpm, BP 89/67 mmHg, RR 34 breaths/min, SpO2 95%, heart rhythm V paced, CVP 9 mmHg.
- Hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, and physical examination findings are also provided.
- Lab results show elevated WBC count, slightly low Hct, and abnormal kidney function tests.
- Assessment and plan include ICU

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic congestive heart failure (EF 15%), implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), and atrial fibrillation. The patient also has a history of subdural hematoma with burr hole evacuation.

The patient's current condition includes symptoms of dyspnea, agitation, and tachycardia. The EKG shows no significant changes, with a rhythm of atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% on BiPAP.

The patient's vital signs indicate a heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 89/67 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and central venous pressure (CVP) of 10 mmHg. The patient is receiving multiple IV medications including lasix, heparin sodium, and omeprazole.

The lab results show elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, slightly elevated creatinine, and abnormal electrolyte levels. The patient's cardiac enzymes (CK, CKMB, troponin-T) are within normal limits.

The patient's fluid balance shows a net loss of 2283 mL and the urine output is 3306 mL. The chest X-ray did not reveal any significant fluid overload.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), who presented with systolic heart failure and an ejection fraction of 15%. The patient also has atrial fibrillation and has undergone burr hole evacuation for a subdural hematoma. The patient is currently in the ICU due to volume overload and worsening renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient's symptoms of agitation, tachypnea, and tachycardia, along with elevated CVP, indicate fluid overload. The patient has already shown improvement with lasix gtt and bolus, as well as diuril. The plan is to continue lasix gtt with a goal UOP of 50-100 cc/hr, monitor CVP, and aim for an I/O balance of -1 to 1.5L for the day.

2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia is likely contributing to poor forward flow and further fluid overload. Increasing carvedilol to 25 mg and consulting with an outpatient cardiologist regarding the use of Coumadin are recommended.

3. Coronary Arteries: The patient has a history of CAD and CABG. Although the patient denies chest pain at this time, it is important to follow up with OSH hospital records for

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He also has systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15% and an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for further evaluation and management of his conditions. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient is volume overloaded, as indicated by his symptoms and fluid balance data. This can lead to worsening heart failure and pulmonary edema. Continuing diuresis with lasix is recommended to manage this condition.

2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia may be contributing to poor forward flow and further fluid overload. Metoprolol can be used for rate control, and Coumadin can be considered in 3 weeks after neurosurgical follow-up.

3. Coronaries: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease post CABG. No recent PCI has been performed, so changing Plavix to aspirin (if approved by neurosurgery) can be considered. Simvastatin should be continued, and metoprolol can replace carvedilol for rate control.

4. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated above the recent baseline. Prerenal azotemia due to poor forward flow may be the cause. Continuing diuresis

The patient has acute renal failure on chronic renal failure, with a baseline creatinine of 1.1 in early [Month], which rose to 1.6 on [12-25] after receiving contrast dye. The patient also has restrictive cardiomyopathy, as evidenced by an echocardiogram showing diastolic heart failure and an ejection fraction (EF) of 55%. The patient is receiving prehydration and mucomyst for catheterization, tight blood pressure control, and diuresis with Lasix. She has pitting edema and is on home Lasix 20mg p.o daily. The patient's rhythm is sinus, and she is on telemetry. Her HTN is being managed with hydralazine, nifedipine, and isordil, while lisinopril is held. The patient's diabetes is managed with lantus and Novolog. She had a large right-sided CVA in [9-/2108] with some regained function. Anemia is present with a hemoglobin level of 29, and iron

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 MULTI LUMEN - STOP [**2109-2-6**] 12:00 PM
 EKG - At [**2109-2-6**] 03:21 PM
   Overnight Events:
   - his CVL was removed in the morning
   - he got 5 mg metolazone in addition to 500 mg of Diuril in the
   morning, as well as a 20 mg lasix bolus
   - in the afternoon patient looked increasingly worse- skin mottled,
   perioral cyanosis, low urine output, agitated; repeat electrolytes
   showed worsening renal function; ABG looked fine with good oxygenation,
   stable pH, although lactate was elevated to 2.7; CXR looked unchanged;
   EKG and cardiac enzymes unchanged
   - we stopped his diuretics
   - after much discussion we decided to give him back some fluids
   (thinking he was intravascularly dry from overdiuresis the last two
   days); we gave him 250 cc IV bolus x2 of normal saline
   - for his respiratory agitation, he got 0.5 mg IV morphine x2
   - we changed PO metoprolol to IV given that he was too agitated to
   tolerate pos; we think better rate control will improve his perfusion,
   and stopping the diuretics may allow us to increase his BB
   - with the fluids and morphine, he calmed down, UOP increased, and his
   overall clinical status improved
   - we obtained [**State 1198**] records from an admission in [**Month (only) 25**] that showed
   he was on dig 0.125 mg and has a questionable history of AF; he has not
   been treated with coumadin in the past
   - discharge meds per that admission [**Date range (1) 14020**]/[**2108**] are as follows: Lasix

   20 daily, aspirin 81 dialy, Novolin 70/30 ASDIR, digoxin 125 mcg daily

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. He presented to the hospital with complaints of shortness of breath and was found to have an elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level, indicating heart failure exacerbation. The patient was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management.

24-hour events:
- The patient had a multi-lumen stop on 02/06/2109 at 12:00 PM.
- An EKG was performed on 02/06/2109 at 03:21 PM.
- The patient's central venous line (CVL) was removed in the morning.
- He received 5 mg metolazone in addition to 500 mg of Diuril in the morning, as well as a 20 mg lasix bolus.
- In the afternoon, the patient looked increasingly worse, with skin mottling, perioral cyanosis, low urine output, and agitation. Repeat electrolytes showed worsening renal function; arterial blood gas (ABG) looked fine with good oxygenation, stable pH, although lactate was elevated to 2.7; chest X-ray (CXR) looked unchanged; EKG and cardiac enzymes unchanged.
- We stopped his diuretics.
- After much discussion, we decided to give him back some

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass graft surgery. He also has systolic congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15%, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), and atrial fibrillation. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with symptoms of volume overload, including fluid retention, increased central venous pressure, and pulmonary edema. 

The patient's current condition is complicated by acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, subdural hematoma post burr hole evacuation, and sleep apnea. The patient's renal function is impaired, as indicated by an elevated creatinine level. He also has poorly controlled blood glucose levels, which have led to episodes of hypoglycemia. 

The patient's medication regimen includes metoprolol, digoxin, furosemide (Lasix), K-dur, simvastatin, glyburide, carvedilol, lisinopril, Plavix, omeprazole, aspirin, Novolin 70/30 insulin, and Keppra. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 99/67 mmHg, heart rate of 86 bpm, respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening heart failure due to fluid overload

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He also has a reduced ejection fraction of 15%, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator, atrial fibrillation, and subdural hematoma with evacuation. The patient presented with volume overload and worsening renal function. He was treated with diuretics, fluids, and morphine for agitation. The patient's condition improved after these interventions. The patient has multiple comorbidities including congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, and sleep apnea.

Potential medical complications:
1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient still shows signs of volume overload despite diuretic therapy. This may lead to further respiratory distress, decreased cardiac output, and worsening renal function.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia could contribute to poor forward flow, worsening renal function, and fluid overload.
3. Acute on Chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, indicating ongoing renal dysfunction. This may require further management of fluid and electrolyte balance, as well as consideration for dialysis.
4. DM: The patient's fasting hypoglycemia has resolved but should continue to be monitored closely due to the risk of fluctuating blood sugar levels.
5. Subdural hematoma s/p Burrhole

   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.

   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.

The patient presented to the ICU with symptoms of volume overload clinically, although no change on chest X-ray. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He also has a history of systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15%, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator, and atrial fibrillation. The patient underwent burr hole evacuation for a subdural hematoma.

The patient presented to the ICU with volume overload clinically, although there were no changes on chest X-ray. The volume overload is believed to be due to excessive intravenous fluids received during surgery in the setting of nodal blocking medication and held diuretics. 

During the overnight period, the patient's condition worsened, with mottled skin, perioral cyanosis, low urine output, agitation, and elevated lactate levels. Repeat electrolytes showed worsening renal function, but arterial blood gas (ABG) looked fine with good oxygenation, stable pH, and an ABG of 7.50/42/113/29/8. Chest X-ray remained unchanged, and cardiac enzymes were unchanged as well.

To address these concerns, the patient's diuretics were stopped, and he was given intravenous fluid boluses. Morphine was administered for respiratory distress, and the patient's agitation improved with the fluids and morphine. The patient's overall clinical status improved.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on digoxin

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 72-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass graft surgery. He also has a low left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15% and has been equipped with a biventricular pacemaker and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). The patient recently underwent a burr hole evacuation for a subdural hematoma. 

The patient presented with volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but then required a fluid bolus to correct volume depletion. He is currently requiring continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea. 

The patient's mental status is being closely monitored, as he is disoriented to place and time but can follow commands. His respiratory effort is assisted by the use of a bipap mask, and he exhibits irregular respirations. His peripheral pulses are palpable, and extremities are warm and well perfused. 

Laboratory results indicate renal failure, with a creatinine level of 2.1 today compared to a recent baseline of 1.2. Other lab values show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, and abnormal liver function tests. Electrolyte levels are within normal range.

Plan:

1. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely secondary to poor forward flow and overdiures

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 CARDIOMYOPATHY, RESTRICTIVE
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - start digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CT today
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping

- The patient underwent speech and swallow evaluation and was placed on a thin liquid/ground solid diet with supervised feeding.

- Omeprazole was changed to lansoprazole.
- Dilantin and heparin sodium (prophylaxis) infusions were documented.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass graft surgery. He has a left ventricular ejection fraction of 15% and has undergone implantation of a biventricular pacemaker and ICD. The patient recently suffered from a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated via burr hole. He presented with symptoms of congestive heart failure, volume overload, and respiratory distress. His mental status is fluctuating, and he requires CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Renal Failure, Acute (Acute Renal Failure, ARF)
   - The patient has an elevated creatinine level of 2.1, indicating acute renal failure. This is likely due to poor forward flow and overdiuresis.
   - Hold diuretics and fluids, monitor intake and output.
   - Start digoxin for cardiac function improvement.
   - Continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status.
   - Consider central access for better measurement of fluid status.
   - Consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function.

2. Cardiomyopathy, Restrictive
   - The patient's low left ventricular ejection fraction (15%) suggests restrictive cardiomyopathy.
   - Continue metoprolol for rate control and uptitrate as needed.
   - No Coumadin for now; can consider this in

   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and cardiac bypass surgery. He has a left ventricular ejection fraction of 15% and has undergone placement of a biventricular pacemaker and ICD. The patient recently had a subdural hematoma evacuation. He presents with volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but then developed hypotension and cool, clammy extremities, indicating potential volume depletion. The patient is currently on CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient's symptoms suggest overdiuresis, leading to fluid overload. This is supported by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and an increase in creatinine levels. Fluid boluses have been given, and diuretics have been held. Monitoring intake and output, starting digoxin, and considering central access for better fluid status assessment are recommended.

2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia is likely contributing to his symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload. Metoprolol will be continued for rate control, and Coumadin may be considered in 3 weeks after a neurosurgical follow-up. Attempting to contact neurosurgery regarding anticoagulation is advised.

3. Coronaries: The patient has a history of CAD

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 72-year-old male who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery and has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He also has a biventricular pacemaker ICD and recently underwent subdural hematoma evacuation. The patient developed volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but subsequently resulted in hypotension and cool, clammy extremities due to overdiuresis. The patient continues to require continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) support and has variable mental status with periods of lucidity.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 2.4, which is improved from a peak of 2.8 during this admission and a recent baseline of 1.2. It is likely prerenal due to poor forward flow and superimposed overdiuresis.

2. Cardiomyopathy, Restrictive: The patient's low LVEF of 15% suggests restrictive cardiomyopathy, which can lead to poor forward flow and contribute to renal failure.

3. Subdural Hematoma (SDH): The patient had a recent subdural hematoma evacuation, and a repeat head CT showed residual acute hemorrhage. However, the neurosurgery team does not believe that this is contributing to the worsening apnea.

4. Fluid Overload

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He also has a biventricular pacemaker, ICD, and recently had a subdural hematoma evacuation. The patient developed volume overload, which responded to diuresis, but then experienced hypotension and cool, clammy extremities due to overdiuresis. He requires continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for central sleep apnea and has variable mental status with periods of lucidity. The patient's current issues include congestive heart failure/fluid overload, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, and subdural hematoma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Congestive Heart Failure/Fluid Overload: The patient's euvolemic state suggests that he is currently not experiencing fluid overload. However, there is a risk of fluid overload due to the previous episodes of overdiuresis and subsequent hypotension. Close monitoring of fluid balance and urine output is crucial.

2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia is likely contributing to his symptoms and poor forward flow, leading to further fluid overload. Titration of metoprolol may be necessary to control the heart rate.

3. Coronary Artery Disease: As a post-CABG

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He also has a low left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15% and has undergone implantation of a biventricular pacemaker and ICD. The patient recently had a subdural hematoma evacuation.

The patient's current condition includes volume overload, which initially responded to diuresis but then developed hypotension and cool clammy extremities, requiring fluid boluses. He continues to require CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea. His mental status remains variable, but there are intermittent periods of lucidity.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient likely experienced overdiuresis, resulting in cold, clammy, mottled extremities and an increase in creatinine. This was corrected with fluid boluses and morphine for respiratory distress. The plan is to hold diuretics and fluids, monitor intake/output, continue digoxin, monitor fluid and respiratory status, consider central access for better fluid status measurement, and consider a repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function.

2. Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia is likely contributing to the patient's symptoms, leading to poor forward flow and further fluid overload. The plan is to continue metoprolol

The patient continues to require CPAP and has variable mental status with periods of lucidity.

1. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, as indicated by an elevated creatinine level. This could be due to prerenal causes such as poor forward flow and overdiuresis.

5. Coronaries: The patient has a history of CAD

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15% and has a biventricular pacemaker ICD. He also has a recent history of subdural hematoma evacuation. The patient developed volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but resulted in subsequent hypotension and cool clammy extremities. He continues to require continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) due to underlying central sleep apnea and has variable mental status with periods of lucidity.

The patient's current medical conditions include congestive heart failure (CHF)/fluid overload, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease (CAD) post CABG, acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus (DM), and a subdural hematoma post burrhole evacuation.

The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening CHF/fluid overload, exacerbation of atrial fibrillation, further deterioration of renal function, poorly controlled DM, and potential neurological issues related to the subdural hematoma.

Overall, the patient requires careful management of his CHF/fluid overload, titration of beta-blocker therapy for atrial fibrillation, monitoring and management of renal function, adjustment of insulin therapy for DM, and follow-up with neurosurgery regarding the subdural hematoma.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) and has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He also has a biventricular pacemaker ICD and recently underwent subdural hematoma evacuation. 

The patient developed volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but subsequently led to hypotension and cool clammy extremities due to overdiuresis. The patient continues to require bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) due to underlying central sleep apnea and has variable mental status with periods of lucidity.

The patient's assessment and plan include the following:

1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient was previously overdiuresed and is now euvolemic to hypovolemic. Small fluid boluses were given overnight, decreasing urine output. Small fluid challenges should be continued for oliguria and digoxin should be continued.

2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia is likely contributing to his symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload. Metoprolol should be uptitrated as needed instead of digoxin. Coumadin may be considered in 3 weeks after a neurosurgical follow-up, and ASA should be continued.

3. CORONARIES: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) after CABG. He denies any chest pain

The patient developed volume overload which responded to initial diuresis, followed by hypotension and cool clammy extremities. Subsequently, the patient experienced overdiuresis, which responded to fluid boluses.

The patient requires BIPAP due to underlying central sleep apnea and has variable mental status with periods of lucidity. The assessment and plan include the following:

2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has tachycardia likely contributing to poor forward flow and further fluid overload. Metoprolol should be uptitrated as needed versus uptitrating digoxin.
